fields.description:
After installation, I had to copy libiconv-2.dll, libcrypto.dll, libssl.dll, and libcurl.dll from:
    C:\Users\<UserID>\AppData\Local\Atlassian\SourceTree\git_local\bin
to:
    C:\Users\<UserID> \AppData\Local\Atlassian\SourceTree\git_local\libexec\git-core

do avoid 'missing dll' errors from git.exe
fields.summary: .dll files missing after install of 1.6.14.0 on Windows 7 Enterprise SP 1
Source tree crashed when opened

fields.description:
I find myself constantly clicking the remote and then trying to find the head commit to rebase in the main view.

It be great to be able to rebase from the branch that is found under the REMOTES section of the app.
fields.summary: Allow to rebase from Remotes

fields.description: Graphical icon buttons on the Windows version of Sourcetree should have tooltip text when hovering the mouse pointer on an icon, putting in a description on what the icon does.
fields.summary: Add descriptive tooltips on all icon buttons on Sourcetree

fields.description:
Please add support for Git for Windows > 2.0 - since 2.0 its possible to have a 64 Bit Version of git installed. SourceTree does not find Git if its installed as 64-Bit.

Git for Windows 2.4.0 can be downloaded here: [https://github.com/git-for-windows/git/releases/tag/v2.4.0.windows.2]


*Work Around*
Add a SymLink to re-create the Git v2.x _bin_ folder.
{code}
C:\Program Files\Git>mklink /D bin cmd
symbolic link created for bin <<===>> cmd
{code}
see https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/SOURCETREEKB/Using+Git+2.x+-+Windows
fields.summary: Add support for Git for Windows 2.4.0

fields.description:
First off, let me say that I totally love SourceTree, it has been my number one tool for years on the Mac. Now I switched to Windows and I'm a bit "surprised" about Sourcetree.

"Surprised", because it is very very slow. I have only 3 projects imported right now (out of 25), but switching between tabs to different projects lags seriously. 

Worst is to check in files. I click on a few files and the app takes about 10 - 30 seconds to refresh the UI. On clicking on the "Commit" button and it will take about 3-6 seconds to show me the commit textarea. 

Commit itself is also extremely slow. I do everything with Gitflow and creating a branch takes about 40 seconds! On the Mac this is a thing of 2 seconds (same project).

Is there anything I can do on my end?
fields.summary: Sourcetree lags and is very slow

fields.description:
First of all, this isn't really SourceTree's fault, but SourceTree could handle it better.

When cloning a repo like https://github.com/textmate/ruby.tmbundle which contains files with names like "Snippets/Hash.new { |hash, key| hash[key] = .. } (Has).plist" (yes, that's a file name), SourceTree crashes. These file names are not valid in Windows. Using git directly just issues an error for those paticular files but SourceTree does not know how to handle them.
fields.summary: SourceTree crashes when cloning repo with invalid file name characters

fields.description: A global git ignore file is created when installing Sourcetree on Windows. By default, the file contains lines to ignore files build by Visual Studio. However, all Dlls are not necessarily build by Visual Studio. so .dll files shouldn't be set to be ignored by default
fields.summary: Default global git ignore file created by Sourcetree shouldn't contain .dll

fields.description:
At the moment its always a bit of a pain to try to remember your jira task number to link your commit to a task. It would be great if you use similar syntax to Jira's @ mention system to initialize a search. For example

1. Select Commit and select the Commit message field
2. Type a basic message like "Fixed the issue relating to task " 
3. then enter the key that triggers the lookup, something like "[" or even jira's "@" which initialises a jira search box in the place of the cursor. 
4. Search for something like "My task title". 
5. In a list of top matches select down to the task you want to link to
6. Hit enter

Source tree should add to the commit message the jira task id and anything else in needs to link to. for example

"Fixed the issue relating to task JIR-395"
fields.summary: Integrated Jira Task Lookup in Commit Message

fields.description:
When cloning a mercurial repository from Bitbucket via the 'Clone in SourceTree' button, if a repository contains any named branches that were closed, they will not appear in the cloned copy. If a subsequent pull is done, they will then appear from which it could be synced.

As an example, see the attached local repository given, and also the public repository here: https://bitbucket.org/ahoffer-tbt/namebranchclosedtest

As you can see from the commits page, the closed branch commit is shown, and is pulled down from an hg clone command when done manually or through TortoiseHg. 

However, when done in Bitbucket through the 'Clone in SourceTree' button, after confirming the clone operation in the dialog box, when looking at the commits, the close branch commit is missing. It can subsequently be pulled manually.
fields.summary: Cloning an hg repository from bitbucket via the 'Clone in Source Tree' Button does not bring over commits with named branches being closed.

fields.description:
When examining the diff of a large file, the automatic refresh of the UI kicks in whilst the app is trying to build the diff.

I know I could slow down the refresh cycle, but then I don't get the fast response when I'm not looking at the large file.

Ideally, the refresh should be halted if the diff process is in play as well as enough buffer time at the end of the diffing process so that it is not stuck in an endless loop of refreshing.

Also, the UI shouldn't refresh unless there is an actual change to the files - which should be a background task and not interfere with me in the foreground.

Maybe an option that if the diffing has taken a long time, rather than presenting a refresh to the files automatically, put a "dirty" marker somewhere which has the implication of "Whilst we were diffing, other changes took place. As the diff took too long, we have halted the refresh until you are ready to restart it".

Basically some better way to handle big diffs that take 20s+ to process.

As an example, the file is PHPMaker's .pmp file for our site is around 4MB and 27000 lines long. This simply takes a while to build the diff when it changes.
fields.summary: Refresh and long file diff conflicting.

fields.description:
Hi
As reported here https://answers.atlassian.com/questions/15281655/answers/15281680
it is possible to commit changes without having seen them.

Imagine you have a lot of changes in a file.
Then not all are shown because of Tool->Options->Diff->Internal Diff View-> Internal Diff View Count-> set to 500 (default). There seems to be good reason for this (performance). I understand that, you cannot say SourceTree is "snappy" to say it mildly.

But, this opens a trap. 
Scenario:
You are about to commit a bunch of files and review them with SourceTree's FileStatus diff display. You scroll through the changes. BUT(!) SourceTree does not show you changes 501 and later!! You think "ok, I can commit this file" but you should perhaps not because change 7xx is critical but you did not noticed it !

Feature Request (proposal):
Do not limit the number of shown diffs to begin with. It's just wrong. If a file with many changes appears, show a dialog noticing the user that he can limit it for performance reason. The dialog should optionally contain  a "don't show this dialog again" checkbox.
After setting a value, the user may have forgotten, that he has set the value once. So, there should be a status bar or floating text on the diff display bottom noticing the user that there are more changes. 
Then, it would be necessary to have a "expand to all changes" or similiar button. It would be very awkward if the user has to go to options and uptick the shown diffs, commit and then downtick the number of shown diffs after commit to have his performance back.

If there is such a concern about performance, then we can assume some users have even lower limits. Which makes the problem worse.
fields.summary: Possible to commit unseen changes

fields.description:
SourceTree supports Jira link highlighting. However, in case of several projects in the seral jiras, sometimes it is not simple to understand, what issue was fixed of the target commit. 
I suggest to to add tooltip for Jira link in the commit with the following information:
# Full link to the target jira (for example, https://myJira03.example.com/browse/PRJ-123)
# Jira issue header of the target issue

Also I'd like to have ability to copy link into the clipboard instead of opening web browser and copying full link from the navigation bar.

All of these improvements are implemented in Chrome, IE and other browsers:
# Try to move mouse to the any link - the http reference will be shown in the bottom panel
# Try to do right-click on the any link - browser suggests you to copy link into the clipboard.
fields.summary: Add tooltip for Jira links

-Initialise an empty repository
-Ensure the repository is set to use the global user information
-Add a file to that repository and commit it

Set a repository-specific user information. This is correctly applied to commits.

fields.description:
Once you have a lot (>10) repositories, browsing through all of them becomes less efficient.

For example, you can have a repository opened in the tab view, and still spend a few seconds searching for it in the left side. It is a pity because some actions (open in explorer) can only be done in the left side.

How others solved it :
- Eclipse lets you sync your source file currently edited to your source files list.
- TortoiseHg workbench sets a bold font on the currently selected repositories...

One of the two would be cool.

Alternative solution : having a filter box or ctrl+f in the repository list.
EDIT : I just noticed that last feature is already implemented in 2.0.. cool :-)

There could be a window which lists the current git-hooks and their types that can be edited right through SourceTree.

fields.description:
This is related to this Bitbucket bug: 
https://bitbucket.org/site/master/issue/10981/team-members-cant-see-teams-on-teams

If a user's access level in a Bitbucket team account are without "Create Repositories" privileges, then the user won't be able to view that team account's repositories in SourceTree's Hosted Repositories. 

When I was invited into team2000002/team~ with a write access, but without "Create Repositories" privileges, I can't view it on Hosted Repositories:

!team2.PNG|thumbnail!
!team1.PNG|thumbnail!

But when I was invited into team2000002/team~ with a write access, and also with "Create Repositories" privileges, I can finally view it on Hosted Repositories:

!team4.PNG|thumbnail!
!team3.PNG|thumbnail!
fields.summary: Repositories not showing in Hosted Repositories if user has no "Create Repositories" privileges in the Bitbucket Team account

fields.description:
When you right click you have the option to "Resolve using Mine" or "Resolve using Their". The pop up asks "Are you sure you want this particular commit ID?" Which is a random string of lots of numbers and letters. I don't know about you, but I never look at my commit ID.

This workflow can be improved in several ways.

1. Just have a "Resolve" option, not two separate Resolve options.
2. The dialog show show "Mine" with the last Commit Description, branch, and the ID. It should also show "Theirs" with it's last Commit Description, branch, and it's ID. The ID is the least important thing in the list.
3. The user can then decide which version to select with more confidence.
fields.summary: Resolve Dialog Should be more helpful

fields.description:
On a Windows environment, SourceTree is (slightly) irritating to use. 
Part of this can be attributed to SourceTree not adhering to the Windows UX guidelines and not behaving like a Windows application.

Example: heavy use of title-case capitalisation where sentence-case should be used
https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/windows/desktop/dn742478.aspx
Bold text on buttons, non-standard fonts?
High visual complexity by having multiple layers of vertical indentation
Use of right-justified labels on left of control

This has a direct impact on acceptance by the users. If the application "feels weird", then the entire process is at risk and users try to minimize the interaction with the application.
fields.summary: Adhere to Windows UX guidelines

fields.description:
KeeAgent is a drop-in replacement for Putty pageant http://lechnology.com/software/keeagent/
It is a plugin for Keepass . 
Putty instantly uses KeeAgent but SourceTree doesn't.

See also https://answers.atlassian.com/questions/13421041/keeagent-integration-with-sourcetree
fields.summary: Allow KeeAgent as SourceTree ssh key provider

fields.description:
SourceTree appears to not honor git config alias.wdiff. Git diff reports no data in the terminal view when lines exceed 2048 bytes. SourceTree itself is showing complete line diffs even with this alias set.

Reproduce is simple, create a valid XML file, with a significant sized line, 4Kb or above, with no trailing \n (Excel worksheet, for example) but long lines. Change one attribute value. The entire line is reported as -/+ in Source tree and is not reported in the terminal window.
fields.summary: SourceTree not honoring wdiff for long XML lines

However, many (German) translated terms are very... weird.

fields.description:
Many windows feature buttons with bold texts.
This is a clear violation of the Windows Usability (UX) Guidelines.
fields.summary: Many buttons on Windows feature bold texts (violates Windows UX guidelines)

fields.description:
1. Create file on branch A
2. Commit/Push
3. Create (and switch to) branch B from branch A
4. Move file into subdirectory and modify contents
5. Commit/Push
6. Switch to branch A
7. Modify file content (in a manner as to not cause a conflict)
8. Commit/Push
9. Merge branch B into branch A

Result:
The file is shown as being moved, but the changes (File Contents) are all highlighted in green, prefixed with +. 

Expected result:
The file is shown as moved and only the change from the branch B is highlighted (this is the behaviour in Stash for this commit)

I cannot view any external diff on the log of the file in the subfolder (the log of the file only shows the changes from branch B). I use DiffMerge as external diff.
fields.summary: Log for modified, moved and merged file shows all contents as new

fields.summary: SourceTree crashes on start

fields.description:
When logged in to my developer computer using Team Viewer (free remote desktop software) SourceTree often fail to render the window when going from minimized back to normal view . The program is running and you can see the icon in the task bar, but when you click the icon to bring up the window nothing happens. The only workaround is to quit SourceTree (right clicking the icon and close window or kill the application with Windows Task Manager and then launch the application again). Then SourceTree will work for a while and then you have to redo the operation. I have not had this problem with any other software.

It might be related to the way Team Viewer injects an extra icon next to the close, minimize, maximize icons in the upper right corner.
fields.summary: Fail to render window when logged in remotely

fields.description:
I've created empty local git repository through console, added origin url (Stash running on local server) and did initial commit with just .gitignore. Then I added another remote url (bitbucket) in the same repo, pulled source from that url and committed to local repo (stash). Then I opened SourceTree and my repo and I could see all commits from both remotes. When I clicked on commit from bitbucket remote (date was before I created local repo) ST crashed.
Now when I open ST and do the same, commit is properly displayed.
fields.summary: SourceTree crashes when clicking on a commit from remote repo

fields.description:
Work on a project including sub-modules.
Update one sub-module, commit changes and push them to the origin.
Align the parent project with the new sub-module commit.
Commit changes on parent project and
 *push them into the origin* => crash
fields.summary: Crash when commit a submodule commit update

fields.description: On Windows 7, if a dark theme is used, font colour on alternating rows in the Log/History are white-on-white, causing visibility issues.
fields.summary: Alternating row colors in the "Log / History" grid are white-on-white while using a dark theme.

fields.description:
Japanese characters garble in diff view though it is UTF-8, whether a file has BOM or not. It only happens on Windows app.

This is how I reproduced:
# Prepare vanilla Windows 7 Pro
# Install Source Tree for Windows 1.6.14.0 (The latest version at this moment)
# Create a local repository
# Add the attached .cs files and commit them
# Delete the comment in line 68 of the files
# Japanese characters become garbled in diff view (See attached screen shot)
fields.summary: Japanese characters are garbled in diff view

fields.description: After a successful commit but failed push (because I needed to do a pull, merge, etc.) SourceTree crashed when I clicked the OK button to dismiss the results dialog.
fields.summary: Crash after failed push (hg)

fields.description:
Created a new private project in bitbucket, with hg as vcs.
Used the "clone in sourcetree" button, which opened sourceTree.

When clicking "clone", I get the following error :

hg clone -b default https://mikarnage@bitbucket.org/mikarnage/bettergdrive C:\Prog\bettergdrive
abort: unknown branch 'default'!
fields.summary: Cannot clone a newly created mercurial bitbucket project
Crash occuring after reactivating Sourcetree window

fields.description:
I am using SourceTree for performing/managing my file commits, pushes, pulls and merges.
I use BeyondCompare as the external Merge/Diff tool and have it set in the options. While managing one of the merge conflicts, I launched the Bcomp 3 window pop up, I see that it comes with 3 panes , each of them ending with  .LOCAL, .REMOTE and .MERGED in theirr file names and the order is same as I mentioned in the Source Tree command line.
**Fair Enough**
Here is the confusion and the issue - 
I notice that the .LOCAL file has the content of the .REMOTE and .REMOTE has my local changes as if it's trying to understand it in exactly opposite way. Just don't get this at all. Do I have a bad setting/config in Bcomp or SourceTree that is resulting in opposite content.
My understanding is 
Local - meaning the file I have made my changes locally and have got the conflict upon, 
while pulling others
..Remote - Is the file/content that has been pushed to pushed to the master ahead of me and is something I am pulling or merging with.

Sometimes I see this in the merged files  <<<< HEAD
========== 
>>>>> 
Can someone tell what when exactly do we get it, and will it ever happen if I use external merge tool like Bcomp. Does GIT put these to indicate something, and we need to manually remove it and save the file to avoid compilation errors (If yes, pretty lame then).
fields.summary: Using BeyondCompare as External Diff/Merge Tool - Local and Remote Copies Reversed
